Award.AwardTitle: CNH: The Coupled Human Health and Environmental Dynamics of Schistosomiasis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecological damage caused by human activity can directly influence infectious diseases and human health, but public health campaigns rarely turn to ecological solutions to mitigate infectious disease risk, instead favoring traditional approaches, such as vaccine development or drug treatment. This research project will conduct an experimental investigation of a novel disease-control strategy that incorporates the reintroduction of native prawns to determine whether they might help reduce the prevalence of the snails that host the parasitic worms for that spread schistosomiasis, which is one of the most prevalent parasitic diseases in the world. The project will test the idea that reintroduction of the native prawns as predators will repair the aquatic food web that has been disrupted by dam construction and significantly reduce transmission of schistosomiasis by reducing the prevalence of the parasites. The project will investigate whether and how prawn restoration can be sustainable as well as add an important protein food source and market resource for the people living along the rivers. The project will provide new understanding regarding the complex interaction of human and natural forces to alter patterns of disease transmission. It will enhance knowledge across a range of fields, including trophic ecology, epidemiology, aquaculture, economics, and other social sciences as well as mathematical modeling. The project therefore will provide new insights regarding how biodiversity may be enhanced, how human health may improve, and how native prawn aquaculture may provide benefits to the rural market economy. The transmission of schistosomiasis by parasites from infected snails when people use open water systems for bathing, washing clothes and equipment, tending livestock, farming, or playing has led to the infection of about 220 million people, with an estimated 200,000 deaths per year from schistosomiasis around the world. More than 95 percent of the infections are occur in Africa, and this project will be based in the Senegal River ecosystem of western Africa, but the project will provide both basic and applied insights regarding the dynamics of coupled natural and human systems related to the transmission of diseases in rivers and other water bodies in other locales, including many in the U.S. The project also will provide special education and training opportunities for post-doctoral researchers as well as graduate and undergraduate students. This project is supported by the NSF Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems (CNH) Program.

The project will be conducted by researchers constituting a team drawn from many different disciplines. They will conduct experiments where prawns will be enclosed at water-use sites and disease transmission will be compared with control sites to determine the effect of prawns on snail abundance and on human infection rates. Reintroduction of the prawns will be combined with drug treatments and will be analyzed with economic models, consideration of human behavior, and monitoring of snail and human infections. The information from these components of the project will be synthesized with mathematical models. This project will contribute to the technology of cultivation of the prawns as part of the ecosystem recovery and augmentation of natural snail predators, and prawn-stocking and harvest strategies will be modeled to seek the best approach to maximize public health while also offering a nutritional and market incentive to sustain prawn populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We advanced knowledge about complex, interacting predator-prey-parasite dynamics.  In laboratory experiments, we showed that Macrobrachium spp. prawns prefer schistosome-infected snails in the laboratory, probably because infected snails are less likely to exhibit anti-predatory behaviors.  

We explored the historical context of schistosomiasis control around the world, through an empirical lens, to identify what has worked in national schistosomiasis control programs, what hasn't, and why. We demonstrated that, over the past century, snail control, through use of molluscicides and biological control, has been the most effective strategy for long-term schistosomiasis reductions at the national and global scales.  Because molluscicides are expensive and have unwanted toxic effects on ecosystems, our work points towards the need for the development of novel, sustainable environmental and snail control strategies to complement traditional drug based control of schistosomiasis.

We expanded our work on dams, prawns, snails, and schistosomiasis beyond Senegal to assess 14 dams in sub-Saharan Africa with upstream catchments spanning more than 4 million km2. We showed that upstream catchments hundreds of kilometers from dams often experienced schistosomiasis increases after dam construction.  Schistosomiasis increased more within prawn ranges, and schistosomiasis decreased overall in the undammed, control watersheds. 

We advanced knowledge on the optimal larviculture protocols for M. vollenhovenii prawns, demonstrating that captive M. vollenhovenii are more cannibalistic, less ammonia-tolerant, and require double the artemia feeding rate than the well-known and often aquacultured congener, M. rosenbergii.   

We completed a before-after-control-impact study that showed strong and significant effects of prawn reintroductions on snails and snail infections in village water access points, but weak effects on infections in children. 

We advanced basic science about the diversity of trematodes in Senegal.  We documented a strong association between schistosome-susceptible snails and the floating plant Ceratophyllum and we demonstrated how this knowledge could be harnessed using drone and satellite imagery, to predict reinfection rates in schoolchildren.  

We advanced social science in an understudied region of the world: household surveys suggested the potential importance of disease transmission on livelihoods and poverty. We found that rural poor villagers understand the dangers of schistosomiasis but feel trapped by poverty, subsistence agricultural livelihoods and lack of safe water options. Many families travel to their fields, to weekly markets, to neighboring villages, and to religious festivals, which can impact the exposure and contamination patterns. We found agricultural activity at the household level (size and type of subsistence crops) affects schistosomiasis reinfection rates.  Exposure, environmental hazard, and vulnerability were all important aspects in explaining variation in risk of reinfection with schistosomiasis.  This is likely generalizable to other environmentally transmitted diseases of humans, and argues for more interdisciplinary studies of risk and more cross-sector solutions.

Executive Summary of Broader Impacts

In addition to our high profile publications that garnered considerable attention from scientists, global citizens, and stakeholders, we led technology transfer for aquaculture of the native African river prawn to a disadvantaged country.  We also wrote book chapters that contribute to graduate education, pioneered new models for schsitosomiasis risk, and used drones for aerial sampling of snail habitat. We quantified the global burden of this environmentally transmitted diseases (and others), and researched new techniques and ideas for practical ecological solutions to reduce disease.  

Media coverage has disseminated results of this work very broadly.  We produced a short documentary with California Academy of Sciences BioGraphic: https://www.biographic.com/protected-by-prawns/which has been broadcasted globally. Our work was also covered by National Geographic?s Phenomena Blog: http://bit.ly/1gKjYLY; NPR?s Science Friday https://www.sciencefriday.com/segments/a-creative-approach-to-controlling-a-deadly-snail/, and BBC news http://www.bbc.com/news/av/science-environment-38572454/river-prawn-versus-schistosomiasis.

On student training, a cumulative 11 graduate students (3 women), 22 undergraduates (11 women), and one high school student (a woman) have been actively engaged in this research during the past five years, with contributions varying from data generation, data management, data analysis, writing, and outreach.  

On outreach, we have developed a public website and a collaborative scientist-citizen initiative called The Upstream Alliance pioneered by scientists and policymakers among a global network of academic institutions, whose aim is to reduce the burden of schistosomiasis in the developing world through natural solutions. We have a website and www.theupstreamalliance.org.  

We developed outreach materials including: a data dissemination website at http://schisto.stanford.edu, a Science Journal for Kids adaptation of one of our publications (On dams, prawns and schistosomiasis) for middle school teaching curriculum in English https://sciencejournalforkids.org/articles/more-river-prawns-less-snail-fever/and French https://www.sciencejournalforkids.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/schisto_article_fr.pdf.  

With the collaboration of the non-profit Ignite Education, Palo Alto, CA, we recruited a science teacher of Carmel Middle School (Carmel by the Beach, CA)  to develop a two-week learning program on Human and Planetary Health, centered on the Diama dam case study.

We supported two Masters in Business Administration student interns.  Each intern spent a summer in Senegal in 2018 and Brazil in 2019, respectively, and prepared technical reports on a market analysis and feasibility for an envisioned for-profit social impact business venture prawn aquaculture to improve livelihoods, generate revenue, and reduce schistosomiasis.
